content: The "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Juvenile Services Improvement Act of 2007" is cited as the short title. It amends Title V of the Public Health Service Act to include mental health services for children, adolescents, and their families. The "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Juvenile Services Improvement Act of 2007" amends Title V of the Public Health Service Act to support programs promoting mental health in children and providing early intervention services. Grants will be distributed equitably across regions, with priority given to comprehensive, community-based prevention programs. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Juvenile Services Improvement Act of 2007 aims to implement a prevention and early intervention program for identifying mental health issues in children and promoting resilience. The program involves families, schools, and communities, coordinates behavioral health services, provides public health education, and offers training and support for service providers and school personnel. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Juvenile Services Improvement Act of 2007 aims to promote healthy emotional development and resilience in children through community support, resources, evaluation of programs, and school-based mental health services. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Juvenile Services Improvement Act of 2007 requires entities receiving awards for school-based mental health services to provide non-Federal contributions, limit the grant duration to 5 years, and conduct evaluations of program effectiveness and outcomes. The program focuses on strengthening families with young children and promoting healthy emotional development. Schools receiving funds must maintain specific ratios of certified staff for student support in mental health and substance abuse prevention. The term 'mental illness' refers to diagnosable mental disorders associated with distress or impaired functioning. 'Mental health problem' refers to symptoms not meeting criteria for a disorder. 'Mental health professional' includes counselors, nurses, psychologists, and social workers. School counselors, nurses, psychologists, and social workers must be licensed or certified in the state. The term 'public entity' includes states, political subdivisions, and Indian tribes. $300,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding for 2009 and 2010 to support school counselors, nurses, psychologists, and social workers in schools. The term 'public entity' includes states, political subdivisions, and Indian tribes. $300,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding for 2009 and 2010 to support school counselors, nurses, psychologists, and social workers in schools. This funding cannot be used to replace or add to other mental health services programs. SEC. 520K INITIATIVE FOR COMPREHENSIVE, INTERSYSTEM MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE TREATMENT PROGRAMS FOR JUVENILES. The Attorney General and the Secretary will award grants for programs addressing the service needs of juveniles with mental illnesses, focusing on diversion from incarceration, providing mental health and substance abuse services as alternatives to incarceration, and offering follow-up services post-discharge from the juvenile justice system. Eligible entities can receive these grants. To be eligible for a grant under this section, an entity must be a State or local juvenile justice, mental health, or substance abuse agency. They need to submit an application with required information, including consent from relevant entities and collaboration with educational and welfare agencies for juvenile services. The entity receiving the grant must coordinate activities with juvenile justice and substance abuse or mental health agencies, prioritize joint applications, and ensure matching funds from non-Federal sources. The grant recipient must allocate funds as specified for the first three years and the fourth and fifth years. In the first fiscal year of receiving the grant, the entity must develop a collaborative plan to provide intensive community services for high-risk juveniles and meet their mental health and substance abuse treatment needs. The plan should also include the exchange of information between agencies to enhance services. In the second through fifth fiscal years of the grant, the grantee must use the funds to provide various services such as assertive community treatment, wrap-around services for juveniles, mental health and substance abuse treatment, case management, education, job training, housing assistance, mentoring programs, and after-school programming. The grant funds are used for school and summer programming, establishing a network of boundary spanners for coordination, cross-system training among police, corrections, and mental health providers, and providing coordinated after-care services. The grant funds are used for after-care programs for juveniles with emotional or mental disorders upon discharge from justice facilities. It also includes purchasing technical assistance, providing services, training personnel, and enhancing collaboration among systems. Boundary spanners are defined as professionals who act as case managers for juveniles with mental disorders and substance abuse addictions in both justice agency facilities and community mental health programs. An entity receiving a grant under this section shall conduct activities to serve at least a single political jurisdiction. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 through 2013. SEC. 4. Funding for emergency mental health and substance abuse services for children affected by public health emergencies. Section 501(m) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to increase the percentage of funds for emergency mental health and substance abuse services for children affected by public health emergencies to 5 percent. Additionally, a condition is added that 2.5 percent of the funds must be specifically allocated for these services. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall apply to grants provided on or after January 1, 2008, including emergencies like natural disasters, transportation accidents, technological disasters, and terrorism. SEC. 5. Crisis response grants to address children's needs are added to Title III of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may award grants to eligible entities to increase coordination and development of disaster preparedness efforts for children. Eligible entities include states, political subdivisions, non-profit agencies, or organizations serving children. Grants must be used for activities related to coordination. The Secretary may award grants to eligible entities for disaster preparedness efforts related to children's physical and health needs. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2008.
